comment.author: 27398485@N08
comment._content: Site of the Mortuary Temple of Queen Hatshepsut, 18th Dynasty. Architect was Senimut. Temple also honored the God Amon Ra. - or Amun Re. Rumored to have been a Coptic Christian monastery around the 7th century. Temple of Deir El-Bahri translated means “Temple of the Northern monastery” and is not its original name. satellite photos of area: www.panoramio.com/photo/849112 www.panoramio.com/photo/92207

comment.author: 25752562@N07
comment._content:
The Valley of the Kings is in the foreground, and is separated from Deir el-Bahri by the mountain ridge. The mortuary temple of Hatshepsut is immediately on the other side of the ridge, out of sight.

Many of these footpaths are believed to have been used by the ancient Egyptians, and are still in use today – I hiked them myself as well.

comment.author: 29001398@N00
comment._content: Interesting image! Is there a date for this one, please? For comparison - this is 2007: It seems that the northern cluster of the stone huts at the top of the cliffs is still buried under the sand! Would it be possible for me to use your image on my web site on the page on the huts at xy2.org/lenka/Huts.html?

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: Unfortunately, this one, like most of these lantern slides, is undated. There's more information about the collection here. And yes, please do use the image on your (fabulous!) website. We ask that you let people know where it comes from and ideally link back to Flickr or the Museum website. Deb Wythe Brooklyn Museum Digital Lab

comment.author: 29001398@N00
comment._content:
Dear Deb, many thanks for your answer and your kind comment on my website! I will add the image with the links to back the Museum site along with my April updates. I might also put the link to Lantern slides you sent, I found that interesting.
Best wishes,
Lenka
